Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: The DNA Barcode Scanner: Democratizing Genetic Information For Conservation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to place the power of genetic identification in the hands of those who need it, at the front lines of conservation. The DNA Barcode Scanner will enable anyone, anywhere, to perform a low-cost, rapid, automated DNA test to validate the identity of a tissue sample, without specialized training, expensive lab-based equipment, reagents, or reliable power, where it is needed most - in the field. This technological advance has the potential to revolutionize species identification to prevent species extinction, to protect consumers and our food supply, and to combat threats to global biodiversity. The innovation's commercial potential includes improving the safety and sustainability of our supply chains, combatting costly environmental fraud, and detecting pests and pathogens that threaten our nation's economy, security, and health. The initial market opportunity is to address unmet demand from seafood suppliers, distributors, and retailers; government regulators and enforcement agents; and conservation and natural resources entities, for increased transparency and integrity of seafood supply chains by ending seafood mislabeling and fraud, which occurs in over 30% the $17.1 billion dollar U.S. seafood market and is worth up to $250,000 per illegal import.

The proposed project will develop the customizable DNA collection, extraction, and amplification cartridge that enables a user to go from tissue sample to species identification in a single device. This project focuses on the scientific and technical challenge of automating sample preparation. The company's goal is to create an integrated device that will validate seafood products (our first market) from sample collection to DNA extraction, DNA amplification, and, ultimately, species identification. The goals of this project are to 1) determine a reliable and intuitive method for collecting DNA from a seafood product and create a prototype collection tool, 2) prototype an easy-to-use and highly flexible DNA extraction and sample preparation component to provide DNA suitable for analysis, and 3) fully integrate microfluidic processes and molecular chemistry (DNA amplification and analysis) with clear validation of multiple species. They will design and test several prototypes of the collection, extraction, and amplification cartridge and test these with users to identify the most robust and simplest method for delivering confident species identification. Their objective is to deliver a fully functional prototype that is intuitive for users and can perform a seafood species validation test in multiple field environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conservation X Labs initiated the development of the DNA Barcode Scanner to revolutionize species identification within international trade and food security to improve our ability to prevent species extinction, protect consumers and our food supply, and combat threats to global biodiversity. This SBIR Phase I research rapidly advanced this innovation and successfully accomplished the goal of developing and iterating on sample collection and analysis of the target genetic sequence.

With the crucial support from the NSF SBIR program, Conservation X Labs is proud to have accomplished our goals. And we are proud that through the completion of this project, we have developed a fully functional prototype of an easy-to-use genetic testing tool designed for use by non-scientists, such as inspectors, wholesale buyers, and enforcement officials. We focused on developing an advanced and remarkably easy to use tool that, in the first instance, can detect illegal or fraudulently mislabeled seafood products. Excitingly, the development of this system also marks the democratization of modern genetic testing for those at the front lines of conservation and sustainability to combat illegal wildlife trafficking, detect species of concern, and maintain the traceability of supply chains. 

Our efforts on this project have produced a complete samples-in to results-out process that can be performed on our integrated device without any additional equipment or supplies. Our system has also been successfully performed by non-scientists (including a high school student). The system we have developed is composed of three components: 1) the genetic testing tool, 2) a disposable cartridge that is pre-loaded with stabilized chemistries necessary for the genetic test, and 3) a sample collection kit that overcomes the challenging and specialized process of collecting a sample by pulling genetic material out of the sample and making that genetic material sufficiently pure for the test to be performed successfully.

In order to accomplish the goal of integrating sample collection and target analysis on our cartridge-based system, we had to accomplish three key objectives supported by NSF: (1) identifying a user-friendly sample collection method, (2) developing a practical DNA collection and preparation tool, and (3) designing the amplification cartridge and species identifying assays. We are also proud to have accomplished our two stretch goals of (4) developing a stabilization and production method for the tests and (5) creating a detection system to monitor the amplification reactions.

Through this SBIR project, we also developed specific chemistries that identify a target with a high-level of confidence from closely related products that are commonly used to disguise an illegal or fraudulent seafood product. A major advantage of our system is that these chemistries can be stabilized in our cartridges so that they can be stored without refrigeration for long periods of time before use. Together, the attributes of the system we developed provide for a tool that can be used by anyone, anywhere to perform a genetic test on a suspicious product.

 


Last Modified: 07/21/2020
Modified by: Paul Bunje

And we are proud that through the completion of this project, we have developed a fully functional prototype of an easy-to-use genetic testing tool designed for use by non-scientists, such as inspectors, wholesale buyers, and enforcement officials. We focused on developing an advanced and remarkably easy to use tool that, in the first instance, can detect illegal or fraudulently mislabeled seafood products. Excitingly, the development of this system also marks the democratization of modern genetic testing for those at the front lines of conservation and sustainability to combat illegal wildlife trafficking, detect species of concern, and maintain the traceability of supply chains. Our efforts on this project have produced a complete samples-in to results-out process that can be performed on our integrated device without any additional equipment or supplies.
